story: This cognacdriven variation on the rye-based Algonquin Cocktail is a tribute to Colin Peter Field, who runs the Hemingway Bar in Paris’s Ritz Hotel.

name: Figetaboutit
instructions: Shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist wrapped around three brandied cherries on a pick.
story: When Lindsay Nader and I were debating potential names for her bittersweet Italian-American whiskey sour, barman Sean Hoard smiled and said “figetaboutit.”

name: Fish House Punch
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with grated nutmeg.
story: The original recipe was mixed with a peach eau de vie aged in wood barrels that hasn’t been produced commercially in over a century.

name: Flora Astoria
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a sprig of dried lavender.
story: Lindsay Nader and Anne Robinson collaborated on this flowery spin on the classic Astoria cocktail, named after the annex added to the Old Waldorf hotel in 1897.

name: Honeymoon Cocktail
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
story: This cocktail has a spirituous backbone that is sure to cast a fog over the most amorous honeymoon.

name: Lake George
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
story: Brian came up with this cocktail while vacationing along the sunny shores of Lake George.

name: La Louche
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
story: “Louche” means “questionable, mischievous behavior.” Consider this cocktail as its inspiration.

name: Nth Degree
instructions: Muddle the sugar cube and bitters. Add everything else, then stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with an orange and lemon twist.
story: Nate was intrigued by spirituous, old-fashioned-style cocktails at Milk & Honey that split a cocktail’s base between two complementary spirits.

ingredients.name: Fee Brothers Whiskey Barrel Aged Bitters

name: Pearl Button
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Top with 1.5 oz. of San Pellegrino Limonata. Garnish with half a grapefruit wheel.
story: The combination of ingredients gave off an opalescent glimmer, reminding John of the pearl buttons on the vest he wore behind the bar.

name: Primavera
instructions: Muddle the Cointreau and vegetables. Add everything else, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled St. George Absinthe-rinsed coupe. Garnish with an orange twist.
story: Before the flowers blossom and the berries ripen, root vegetables such as fennel and celery are all you can get at the market until flowering shoots such as asparagus appear.

name: Prince Edward
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist.
story: Stan Jones’s recipe didn’t include bitters, but I felt a couple dashes of orange bitters improved the drink.

ingredients.name: Compass Box Oak Cross Blended Malt Scotch Whisky

name: Rosita
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist.
story: Gary Regan popularized this drink, sans the dash of bitters, which he added along with a tad more tequila.

name: Royal Bermuda Yachtclub Cocktail
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lime wheel.
story: After reading about this drink in Vintage Spirits and Forgotten Cocktails in 2004, I picked up a bottle of Velvet Falernum and have stocked it in all the bars I’ve run ever since.

name: Rusty Nail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.
story: According to David Wondrich, the B.I.F. cocktail, composed of Scotch and Drambuie, first appeared in 1937. Now known as the Rusty Nail, the recipe under this name didn’t appear in popular cocktail books until the 1970's.

name: Sazerac

story: The Sazerac is the official cocktail of New Orleans.

name: Shiso Malt Sour
instructions: Shake with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a shiso leaf.
story: This cocktail was inspired by the refreshing Japanese highball and the herbaceous shiso leaf common in Japanese cuisine.

name: Silver Lining
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with grated nutmeg.
story: A light, refreshing whiskey sour variation intended to show the softer side of rye.

name: Ti' Punch

story: Ed Hamilton, who exports rhum from Martinique, is largely responsible for importing this Caribbean classic to the United States.

name: Tipperary Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist.
story: Named after the county in Ireland, this classic appears in Ensslin's 1916 guide.

name: Up To Date

name: Vaccari

ingredients.name: Chamomile-Infused Compass Box Asyla Blended Scotch Whisky

name: Vauvert Slim

story: Vauvert was home to a Carthusian monastery where Francois Hannibal d’Estrees presented the monks with a manuscript for 'elixir of long life' in 1605.

name: Vieux Carré
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.
story: Named after the French Quarter in New Orleans, this recipe was first served at the Hotel Monteleone in the late 1930s.

name: Blackstar
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a star anise pod.
story: The Blackstar was created with Smirnoff Black, a full-bodied vodka that isn’t available in the U.S., and named after the whole star anise pod that floats on the surface as an aromatic garnish.

name: Black Thorn (English)
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist.
story: The sloe berries used to produce Plymouth Sloe Gin are harvested from blackthorn bushes that grow uncultivated throughout England.

name: Black Thorn (Irish)
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled, St. George Absinthe-rinsed coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist.
story: Although this drink wasn’t named after the Irish whiskey (which was launched in 1934), the higher proportion of malt whiskey in Black Bush gives it the body to stand up to the absinthe and bitters.

name: Black Thorn Rose
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
story: To enhance the primary botanical in Hendrick’s Gin, David came up with this rose-accented variation on the classic that employs Lillet Rouge, Dubonnet’s Bordelaise brethren.

name: Blinker
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
story: Ted Haigh’s Vintage Spirits and Forgotten Cocktails jump-started the classic cocktail renaissance in 2004 by featuring lost drinks such as the Blinker.

name: Café Arroz
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with grated cinnamon.
story: Tequila and horchata, two staples of Mexican cuisine, just happen to work really well in place of vodka and cream in the White Russian cocktail.

story: An ancestor of the Aviation Cocktail, the name references Dutch genever, not the cursed ship forever lost at sea.

name: Fog Cutter
instructions: Shake with ice and pour unstrained into a chilled tiki mug. Float .5 oz. of Lustau Cream Sherry on top. Garnish with a mint sprig.
story: Tiki historian Jeff Berry called this drink “the Long Island Iced Tea of exotic drinks.”

name: Framboise Fizz
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe. Top with 2 oz. of Lindemans Framboise Lambic. No garnish.
story: Michael Klein chose Framboise, a Belgian ale produced by combining fresh raspberries and young lambic, to complement two old friends: tequila and chocolate.

ingredients.name: Marie Brizard White Crème de Cacao

name: Plátanos en Mole Old Fashioned
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a pinch of ground chili.
story: Inspired by the classic dessert, this cocktail was first served at the Star Chefs International Chef’s Conference in New York City.

name: Prince of Wales
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
story: Albert Edward, Prince of Wales and son of Queen Victoria, was the first member of the British royal family to visit North America, in 1860.

name: Rye Witch
instructions: Add the bitters and sugar cube to a mixing glass and muddle to a paste. Add everything else, then stir with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass. Twist an orange peel over the surface and discard.
story: I tend to include “witch,” “strega” in Italian, in a drink’s title whenever we mix with it.

name: Sage Old Buck
instructions: Muddle the black peppercorns with the simple syrup. Add everything else, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Garnish with a smacked sage leaf.
story: We sorted all the produce and chose vanilla, black pepper, and sage to pair with the malt.

name: Fish House Punch
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with grated nutmeg.
story: The original recipe was mixed with a large quantity of spirits in a punch bowl for the members of the State in Schuylkill, a social club founded in Philadelphia in 1732.

ingredients.name: Combier Crème de Pêche de Vigne

name: Gold Rush
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice. No garnish.
story: T. J. Siegal created this modern classic at Milk & Honey. It is essentially a Whiskey Sour with honey syrup instead of simple syrup.

name: Harvest Moon
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with grated nutmeg.
story: This cocktail was inspired by the seasonal transition from summer to fall, using local ingredients like Chardonnay from Long Island.

name: Pearl of Puebla
instructions: Muddle the oregano and agave nectar. Add everything else, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
story: Fashioned as a Mexican rendition of Audrey Saunders’s French Pearl, this uses two staples of Puebla cuisine: mezcal and fresh oregano.

name: Perfect Pear
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled, half sugar-rimmed coupe. No garnish.
story: Marco created this drink for his ex-wife, Sarah, naming it in honor of their marriage and the King Crimson song “Three of a Perfect Pair.”

name: Pharaoh Cooler
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Top with 1 oz. Club Soda. No garnish.
story: Named after the mythic Egyptian origin of watermelon seeds, this drink was so good we put it on the menu after Jack McGarry mixed it at PDT.

name: Persephone
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
story: According to Greek Mythology, the seasons were a result of Persephone’s abduction by Hades; nature suffered while her mother, Demeter, searched for her.

name: Pimms Cup
instructions: Muddle the cucumber and simple syrup. Add Pimms and lemon juice, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Top with 1 oz. Fever-Tree Ginger Ale. Garnish with a cucumber wheel.
story: James Pimm became famous for his “house cup,” a gin sling with a proprietary mix of liqueurs and fruit extracts in the 19th century.

name: Paddington
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled, St. George Absinthe-rinsed coupe. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.
story: Named after the marmalade-loving bear from Michael Bond’s children’s stories, this is a variation on the Fitzgerald cocktail that substitutes rum for gin.

name: Pumpkin Toddy
instructions: Add everything to a pre-heated heatproof mug and stir. Top with 5 oz. hot water and stir. Garnish with grated cinnamon.
story: Originally, toddies were prepared hot or cold in the 18th century with a spirit, sugar, water, and sometimes nutmeg. The formula has become considerably more involved in the 21st century.

ingredients.name: Deep Mountain Grade B Maple Syrup

name: Sazerac
instructions: Muddle the sugar and bitters, then add the whiskey and ice. Stir and strain into a chilled, Vieux Pontarlier Absinthe-rinsed rocks glass. Twist a lemon peel over the surface and discard.
story: This cocktail became synonymous with both Sazerac de Forge et Fils Cognac, which was originally used to prepare the drink, and later with the Sazerac coffee house that Thomas Handy took over in the 1870s.

name: Seelbach Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Top with 2 oz. Moët Imperial Champagne. Garnish with an orange twist.
story: Chicagoan Adam Seger discovered this pre-Prohibition recipe during his tenure at Louisville’s historic Seelbach Hotel in 1995.

name: Professor

story: The Professor is Michael’s rum-based variation on the Chancellor cocktail from Frederick Birmingham’s Esquire Drink Book.

name: Remember the Maine
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled, St. George Absinthe-rinsed coupe. Garnish with one brandied cherry.
story: Baker describes this as a hazy memory from Havana during the 1933 revolution, noting it should be 'handled with care.'

name: Sazerac
instructions: Muddle the sugar and bitters, then add the whiskey and ice. Stir and strain into a chilled, Vieux Pontarlier Absinthe-rinsed rocks glass. Twist a lemon peel over the surface and discard.
story: This cocktail became synonymous with both Sazerac de Forge et Fils Cognac, which was originally used to prepare the drink, and later with the Sazerac coffee house that Thomas Handy took over in the 1870s, when he changed the base spirit to rye whiskey.

name: Seelbach Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Top with 2 oz. Moët Imperial Champagne. Garnish with an orange twist.
story: Chicagoan Adam Seger discovered this pre-Prohibition recipe during his tenure at Louisville’s historic Seelbach Hotel in 1995.

name: Shiso Malt Sour
instructions: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a shiso leaf.
story: This cocktail highlights the delicate herbal notes of shiso leaf paired with the complexity of Japanese malt whisky.

name: Ti-Punch
instructions: Squeeze the lime disc on both sides (to express the oil from the peel and juice from the flesh) into a chilled rocks glass. Add everything else and top with pebble ice. Swizzle, then top with more pebble ice and swizzle again.
story: Ed Hamilton, who exports rhum from Martinique, is largely responsible for importing this Caribbean classic to the United States.

name: Tom Collins
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Top with 2 oz. Club Soda. Garnish with a lemon wheel and a brandied cherry.
story: This cocktail was named after John Collins, a waiter at Limmer’s Hotel in London, who was famous for his gin punch.

name: Vieux Carré
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over a large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.
story: Named after the French Quarter in New Orleans, this drink was created at the Hotel Monteleone’s Carousel Bar in the 1930s.
